verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:1
verses.text: First Part  Ephraim the Syrian.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:2
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:3
verses.text: —Summary of the Authenticated Facts of His Life.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:4
verses.text: All that is known, on early and trustworthy evidence, of the person and life of Ephraim may be briefly summed up.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:5
verses.text: He was born within the Roman pale, in the ancient and famous city of Nisibis in Mesopotamia, in, or before, the earliest days of the reign (a.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:7
verses.text: 306–337) of Constantine the Great: he was a disciple of St.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:8
verses.text: Jacob, Bishop of that city, who died a.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:9
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:10
verses.text: 338: and he lived in it, under Jacob and the three Bishops who successively followed him, through three unsuccessful sieges laid to it by Sapor, King of Persia, down to its final surrender under the terms of the ignominious peace concluded with Sapor by the Emperor Jovian after the defeat and death of his predecessor Julian (a.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:11
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:13
verses.text: Nisibis was then abandoned by its Christian inhabitants; and Ephraim finally settled at Edessa, and took up his abode as a "Solitary" in a cell on the "Mount of Edessa"—a rocky hill close to the city, where many anchorites sought retreat.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:14
verses.text: Here he rose into repute as a teacher, and a champion against heresy; and no less as an ascetic and saint.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:15
verses.text: The fame of St.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:16
verses.text: Basil, metropolitan of Caesarea in Cappadocia (370–379), drew him from his solitude to visit that great prelate and doctor, and from him he received the diaconate; but (though some affirm that he was advanced to the priesthood) it is agreed that he never became a Bishop.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:17
verses.text: He died at an advanced age, in his retreat, in the year 373 according to most authorities, but some suppose him to have lived to 378.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:18
verses.text: He was a most copious writer, and left an immense quantity of writings of which a large part is extant,—Sermons, Commentaries, and Hymns.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:19
verses.text: These constitute such a body of instruction in the substance of Scripture and the faith of the church, that they have justly earned for him the title of malpono, or teacher.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 1:20
verses.text: And not only have his Hymns done much to shape the ritual of the Syrian Churches, in which large portions of them are embodied, but to his Sermons this singular honour is paid, that lessons selected from them were appointed, and are still read, in the regular course of public worship.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 2:1
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 2:2
verses.text: —Materials for His Biography.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 2:3
verses.text: Fuller details, of more or less authentic character, are forthcoming in many quarters.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 2:4
verses.text: In Syriac, we have two Lives, a longer and a shorter; but whether the latter is an abridgment of the former, or is rather the nucleus from which the other has been expanded, is questionable.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 2:5
verses.text: Of both alike, the date and the authorship are undetermined.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 2:6
verses.text: The longer of the two is entitled, the History [tash itha] of the holy Mar Ephraim.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 2:7
verses.text: It varies not a little in the two copies of it [the Vatican and the Parisian] which have been edited; and contains many things that are not easily credible, and some things that are irreconcilable with one another, or with established facts.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 2:8
verses.text: In the main facts, however, this History is borne out by the Greek authorities—the narrations of three fifth-century historians, Socrates, Sozomen and Theodoret, the brief notices of Jerome, De Viris Illustribus (392), and of Palladius, in his Lausiac History (circ.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 2:10
verses.text: , and (what is of most weight) the almost contemporary biographical particulars contained in the Encomium pronounced on Ephraim by Gregory of Nyssa.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 2:11
verses.text: Other Greek Lives are extant;—one which bears the name of a writer coeval with Gregory, Amphilochius of Iconium, but is certainly by a later hand; one anonymous, and one ascribed to Simeon the Metaphrast, a writer of the tenth century.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 2:12
verses.text: We proceed to give an outline of the contents of the Syriac History, adding to it here and there such further noteworthy details or incidents as have reached us from the other sources indicated.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 2:13
verses.text: Further on, it will be our business to examine this narrative and ascertain how far its statements are in themselves credible, or attested by other and earlier evidence.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:1
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:2
verses.text: —The Life, as Amplified by Mediaeval Biographers.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:4
verses.text: His Early Years.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:5
verses.text: —Ephraim, according to this biography, was a Syrian of Mesopotamia, by birth, and by parentage on both sides.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:6
verses.text: His mother was of Amid (now Diarbekr) a central city of that region; his father belonged to the older and more famous City of Nisibis, not far from Amid but near the Persian frontier, where he was priest of an idol named Abnil (or Abizal) in the days of Constantine the Great (306–337).

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:7
verses.text: This idol was afterwards destroyed by Jovian (who became Emperor in 363 after the extinction of the Flavian dynasty by the death of Julian).

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:8
verses.text: In Nisibis, then included within the Roman Empire, Ephraim was born.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:9
verses.text: The date of his birth is not stated, but it cannot have been later than the earliest years of Constantine's reign.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:10
verses.text: Though the son of such a father, he was from his childhood preserved, by Divine grace which "chose him like Jeremiah from his mother's womb," from all taint of idolatrous worship and its attendant impurities, to be, like St.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:11
verses.text: Paul, a "chosen vessel" to spread the light of truth and to quench heresy.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:12
verses.text: The biographer records farther on, but without fixing its time, an intimation of his future work which Ephraim himself relates in his "Testament" as belonging to the days "when his mother carried him on her bosom".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:13
verses.text: He saw in dream or vision a vine springing from his mouth, which grew so high as to fill all that was under the heavens, and produced clusters whereon the fowls of the air fed, and which multiplied the more, the more they were fed on.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:14
verses.text: These clusters (the Testament explains) were his Sermons; the leaves of the vine, his Hymns.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:15
verses.text: But his entrance into the Christian fold was not to be without hindrance and suffering.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:16
verses.text: His father, finding the youth one day in converse with some Christians, was filled with anger, chastised him with cruel and almost fatal severity, and repaired to the shrine of his god to seek pardon for his son by sacrifice and prayer.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:17
verses.text: A voice issuing from the idol rejected his intercession, warned him that his son was destined to be the persecutor of his father's gods, and commanded his expulsion from home.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:18
verses.text: The father obeyed: the son received the sentence with joy, and went out from his father's house, carrying nothing with him and not knowing whither he went.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:19
verses.text: His way was divinely directed to the famous and saintly Bishop, Jacob of Nisibis, to whom he told his story and by whom he was affectionately welcomed and admitted into the number of "Hearers,"—that is, Catechumens in the first stage of preparatory instruction.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:20
verses.text: From the first he showed himself a diligent disciple, in fasting and prayer, and in daily attendance on the teaching of the Scriptures.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:21
verses.text: He frequented the Bishop's abode, imitated his virtues, attracted his special notice, and acquired a high place in his love as well as in that of all the Church.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:22
verses.text: A slanderous charge, however, was laid against him in his youthful manhood, which, but for supernatural interposition granted to his prayer, would have ruined his good name.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:23
verses.text: A damsel of noble birth had been seduced by an official (Paramonarius, i-e:, sacristan, or perhaps rather, steward) of the church, named likewise Ephraim.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:24
verses.text: When pregnancy ensued and her frailty was detected, she at the instance of her paramour charged Ephraim the pious Catechumen as being the author of her shame.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:25
verses.text: Her father laid the matter before the Bishop, who in much grief and consternation summoned his disciple to answer the accusation.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:26
verses.text: The youth received it at first in amazed silence; but finally made answer, "Yea, I have sinned; but I entreat thy Holiness to pardon me".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:27
verses.text: Even after this seeming acknowledgment of guilt, however, the Bishop was unconvinced, and prayed earnestly that the truth might be revealed to him: but in vain,—a more signal clearing was in store for the humble and blameless youth.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:28
verses.text: When the child of shame was born, and the father of the frail damsel required him to undertake the charge of it, he repeated his seeming confession of guilt to the Bishop; he received the infant into his arms: he openly entered the church carrying it; and he besought the congregation with tears, saying, "Entreat for me, my brethren, that this sin be pardoned to me".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:29
verses.text: After thus bearing for some days the burden of unmerited reproach, he perceived the great scandal caused to the people, and began to reflect that his meek acceptance of calumny was doing harm.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:30
verses.text: On the following Sunday, therefore, after the Eucharist had been administered, he approached the Bishop in church in presence of the people, carrying the infant under his mantle, and obtained his permission to enter the bema (not the pulpit, but the raised sanctuary where the altar stood).

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:31
verses.text: Before the eyes of the astonished congregation, he produced the babe, held it up in his right hand, facing the altar, and cried aloud, "Child, I call on thee and adjure thee by the living God, who made heaven and earth and all that therein is, that thou confess and tell me truly, who is thy father?" The infant opened its mouth and said, "Ephraim the paramonarius".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:32
verses.text: Having thus spoken, it died that same hour.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:33
verses.text: The people and the Bishop received this miraculous vindication of the wrongfully accused with amazement and tears; the father of the sinful mother fell on his knees and cried for forgiveness; the true partner of her sin fled and was seen in Nisibis no more; Satan was confounded; and Ephraim was restored to more than all the favour and affection he enjoyed before.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:34
verses.text: Not long after, the young disciple received a singular proof of the high esteem in which he was held by his Bishop.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:35
verses.text: When summoned with the other prelates to the great Council of Nicaea (a.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:36
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:37
verses.text: 325), Jacob took Ephraim with him as his attendant or secretary, and brought him into that holy Synod.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:38
verses.text: It is to be inferred that a youth so chosen must have shown early maturity and zeal for the Faith.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:39
verses.text: His presence on this first great battlefield of the Church's war against heresy must have given a keen stimulus to his polemic activity, and influenced his subsequent life as a student and teacher of theology.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:41
verses.text: Siege of Nisibis.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:42
verses.text: —After some years his course of assiduous study, obedience, and devout piety, was rudely broken by the alarm of war.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:43
verses.text: Soon after the death of Constantine (a.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:44
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:45
verses.text: 337), Sapor, king of Persia was moved to seize the opportunity offered by the removal of the great Emperor and the inexperience of his sons, and to attempt the recovery of the provinces on the Tigris which had been ceded by Narses his predecessor to Diocletian (under the treaty of a.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:46
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:47
verses.text: 297), so as to push his border westward in advance of the line which had for forty years defined the eastern limits of the Roman Empire.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:48
verses.text: To this end it was essential that he should obtain possession of Nisibis, the strength and situation of that city marking it as a necessary safeguard for the frontier he sought to attain; and to it accordingly he laid siege in great force.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:49
verses.text: After seventy days' successful resistance, he had recourse to a novel mode of assault by which the city was wellnigh overpowered.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:50
verses.text: The river (Mygdonius) which flowed through it was by his orders embanked and its waters intercepted, and then let loose so as to bear with destructive rush against the city wall.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:51
verses.text: It gave way; and Sapor prepared to enter and take possession.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:52
verses.text: To his dismay he found his advance vigorously repelled; he saw the breach filled by a fresh wall, manned and equipped with engines of war.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:53
verses.text: The holy Bishop Jacob and the devout Ephraim, by their unceasing prayers within the church and their exhortations, had stimulated the garrison and the people to accomplish this work with incredible rapidity, and had secured the divine blessing on its timely completion.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:54
verses.text: But a more amazing sight than the newly-built wall awaited Sapor.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:55
verses.text: On the ramparts there appeared a Figure in royal apparel of radiant brightness,—the Emperor Constantius in outward semblance; though he was known to be far off, in Antioch.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:56
verses.text: Sapor in blind fury assailed this majestic phantom with missiles, but soon desisted when he perceived the futility of his attack.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:57
verses.text: His final discomfiture was brought to pass by Ephraim.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:58
verses.text: Having first sought and obtained the Bishop's sanction, he ascended a tower whence he could view the besieging host, and there he offered prayer to God that He should send on them a plague of gnats and mosquitos, and show by what puny agents Divine Power could effectually work the ruin of its adversaries.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:59
verses.text: The prayer was instantly answered by a cloud of these insects, tiny but irresistible assailants, descending on the Persian host.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:60
verses.text: Maddened by this plague, the horses flung their riders; the elephants broke loose and trampled down the men; the camp was thrown into irretrievable confusion; a storm of wind, rain, and thunder (adds another chronicler) enhanced the panic; and Sapor was forced to raise the siege and retire with ignominy and heavy loss instead of success.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:61
verses.text: Soon after, the saintly Bishop Jacob died, in the fulness of his virtues and his fame; and Ephraim in deep affliction conducted his funeral.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:63
verses.text: Removal to Edessa.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:64
verses.text: —Our biographer then, passing over the remaining years of Constantius, goes on to the accession of Julian (a.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:65
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:67
verses.text: The troubles of the intervening period he assigns to the reign of Constans, whom (though he died before his brother Constantius) he supposes to have reigned after him and before Julian.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:68
verses.text: He records the persecutions suffered by the Christians under the latter, the judgment that overtook him in his defeat and death by the hands of the Persians, the succession of Jovian, and the treaty concluded by him with Sapor, under which Nisibis was surrendered to Persia and emptied of its Christian inhabitants.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:69
verses.text: Of Ephraim he tells us only that he raised his voice against Julian and his persecutions, and remained in Nisibis until its surrender, and then retired to a place called Beth-Garbaia, where he had been baptized at the age of eighteen and had received his first instruction in the Scriptures and in psalmody.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:70
verses.text: Persecution having arisen there against the Church, he fled to Amid, where he spent a year; and thence proceeded to Edessa (now Urfa), which city, as soon as he came in sight of it, he fixed on as his permanent and final abode.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:71
verses.text: As he was about to enter it, an incident occurred which nearly all the narratives of his life relate with variations, and which the historian Sozomen states to have been recorded in one of the writings of Ephraim himself.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:72
verses.text: Beside the river Daisan which surrounds the city, he saw some women washing clothes in its waters.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:73
verses.text: As he stood and watched them, one of them fixed her eyes on him and gazed at him so long as to move his anger.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:74
verses.text: "Woman," he said, "art thou not ashamed?" She answered, "It is for thee to look on the ground, for from thence thou art; but for me it is to look at thee, for from thee was I taken".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:75
verses.text: He marvelled at the reply and acknowledged the woman's wisdom; and left the spot saying to himself, "If the women of this city are so wise, how much more exceedingly wise must its men be!"  Other authorities (including Ephraim's contemporary, Gregory of Nyssa, who professes to collect the facts of his Encomium exclusively from Ephraim's own written remains) give a somewhat different turn to this story.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:76
verses.text: According to them, Ephraim approached the city, praying and expecting to meet at his first entrance there some holy and wise man by whose converse he might profit.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:77
verses.text: The first person whom he encountered at the gate was a harlot.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:78
verses.text: Shocked and bitterly disappointed, he eyed her, and was passing on; but when he noticed that she eyed him, in turn, he asked the meaning of her bold gaze.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:79
verses.text: In this version of the incident, her answer was, "It is meet and fit that I gaze on thee, for from thee, as man, I was taken; but look not thou on me, but rather on the ground whence thou wast taken".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:80
verses.text: Ephraim owned that he had learned something of value even from this outcast woman; and praised God, who from the mouth of such an unlooked-for teacher, had fulfilled his desire for edification.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:81
verses.text: Another woman of Edessa is related by some of these authorities to have accosted the holy man, expecting that, even if she failed to tempt him to unchastity, she might at least move him to the sin, against which he strove no less sedulously to guard himself, of anger.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:82
verses.text: He affected to yield to her solicitation; but when she invited him to fix on a place of assignation, he proposed that it should be in the open and frequented street.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:83
verses.text: When she objected to such shameless publicity, he replied, "If we are ashamed in sight of men, how much more ought we to be ashamed in the sight of God, who knows all secret things and will bring all to His judgment!" By this reply the woman was moved to repentance and amendment, and gave up her sinful life,—and finally (as some add) retired from the world into a convent.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:84
verses.text: In Edessa, Ephraim at first earned a humble livelihood in the service of a bath-keeper, while giving his free time to the task of making the Scriptures known to the heathen who then formed a large part of the population of the city.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:85
verses.text: But before long he was led, by the advice of a monk whom he casually met, to join himself to one of the Solitaries (or anchorites) who dwelt in the caves of the adjacent "Mount of Edessa" (a rocky range of hills, now Nimrud Dagh).

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:86
verses.text: There he passed his time in prayer, fasting, and study of the Scriptures.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:87
verses.text: But a divine intimation was sent to call him back from his retreat into active life in the city.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:88
verses.text: A vision came to the Solitary under whom Ephraim had placed himself.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:89
verses.text: This man, as he stood at midnight outside his cell after prayer and psalmody, saw an angel descending from heaven and bearing in his hands a great roll written on both sides, and heard him say to them that stood by, "To whom shall I give this volume that is in my hands?" They answered, "To Eugenius the Solitary of the desert of Egypt".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:90
verses.text: Again he asked, "Who is worthy of it?" They answered, "Julian the Solitary".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:91
verses.text: The Angel rejoined, "None among men is this day worthy of it, save Ephraim the Syrian of the Mount of Edessa".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:92
verses.text: He, to whom this vision came, at first regarded it as a delusion; but he soon found reason to accept it as from God.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:93
verses.text: Visiting Ephraim's solitary cell, he found him engaged in writing a commentary on the Book of Genesis, and was amazed at the exegetical power shown in the work of a writer so untrained.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:94
verses.text: When this was speedily followed by a Commentary on Exodus, the truth of the vision became apparent, and the Solitary hastened to the "School" of Edessa and showed the book to "the doctors and priests, and chief men of the city".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:95
verses.text: They were filled with admiration, and when they learned that Ephraim of Nisibis was the author, and heard of the vision by which his merit was revealed, they went at once to seek him out in his retreat.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:96
verses.text: In his modesty he fled from their approach; but a second divine vision constrained him to return.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:97
verses.text: In the valley where he had sought to hide, an Angel met him and asked, "Ephraim, wherefore fleest thou?" He answered, "Lord, that I may sit in silence, and escape from the tumult of the world".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:98
verses.text: "Look to it," rejoined the Angel, "that the word be not spoken of thee, Ephraim hath fled from me as an heifer whose shoulder hath drawn back from the yoke" (Hos.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:99
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:101
verses.text: 11—quoted loosely).

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:102
verses.text: Ephraim pleaded with tears, "Lord, I am weak and unworthy;" but the Angel silenced his excuses with the Saviour's words, No man lighteth a candle and putteth it under a bushel, but on a candlestick that all may see the light (St.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:103
verses.text: Matth.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:104
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:105
verses.text: 5, St.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:106
verses.text: Luke xi.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:108
verses.text: Accepting the rebuke, Ephraim returned to Edessa, with much prayer for strength from on high, to combat false doctrine.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:109
verses.text: There he was ill received, and taunted as one who had fled in hypocritical affectation of reluctance, and was now returning in vainglorious quest of applause.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:110
verses.text: This reproach he met with the meek reply, "Pardon me, my brethren, for I am a humble man;" at which they cried out the more against him, "Come, see the madman, the fool!" He held his ground notwithstanding, and taught many.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:111
verses.text: But this work which his adversaries failed to put down, the over-zeal of an admirer brought to a sudden close.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:112
verses.text: One of the recluses of the Mount, having occasion to visit the city, saw him and followed him crying, "This is the fan in the Lord's hand, wherewith He wilt purge all His floor, and the tares of heresy: this is the fire whereof our Lord said, I am come to send fire on the earth" (St.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:113
verses.text: Matth.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:114
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:116
verses.text: Luke xii.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:118
verses.text: Hearing this, certain chief men of the city, heretics, heathens, and Jews, seized him and drew him outside the gates, stoned him and left him wellnigh dead.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:119
verses.text: Next morning he fled back to his cell on the Mount.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:121
verses.text: Work as a Teacher.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:122
verses.text: —There, he gave himself to the work of refuting with his pen the heresies and misbeliefs of his time, which he had thus been hindered by violence from combating in speech.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:123
verses.text: Disciples gathered round him, and a school formed itself under the teacher in his retirement.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:124
verses.text: The names are recorded by our narrator of Zenobius, Simeon, Isaac, Asuna, and Julian.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:125
verses.text: Others add those of Abraham, Abba, and Mara.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:126
verses.text: All these are named with favour in his Testament (a document of which we shall treat hereafter) except Isaac; but two others, Paulinus and Aurit (or Arnad) are denounced as false to the Faith.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:127
verses.text: The biographer introduces into his narrative of this stage of Ephraim's life an account of his famous dream of the vine (above referred to), which foreshowed his future fertility as a writer, as related in his Testament.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:128
verses.text: It will be given farther on, in his own words.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:129
verses.text: Remote and isolated as was his abode, the fame of the illustrious Basil, Archbishop of Caesarea in Cappadocia, reached him there, and moved in him a desire to see and hear so great a divine.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:130
verses.text: He prayed for divine guidance in the matter; and in answer a vision was sent to him.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:131
verses.text: Before the Holy Table there seemed to stand a pillar of fire, whereof the top reached unto heaven, and a voice from heaven was heard to cry, "Such as thou seest this pillar of fire, such is the great Basil".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:133
verses.text: Journey to Egypt, and Sojourn There.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:134
verses.text: —Thus encouraged, Ephraim set out on his journey, taking with him an interpreter, for he was unable to speak Greek.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:135
verses.text: In the first instance, however (according to the History), he made his way, not to Cappadocia, but to a seaport (not named by the writer—but probably Alexandretta is meant) where he took ship for Egypt.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:136
verses.text: In the voyage the ship encountered perils, first in a storm, and afterwards from a sea-monster, but was delivered from both by his faith, which enabled him with words of power and the sign of the cross to rebuke the winds and waves into calm, and to slay the monster.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:137
verses.text: Arrived in Egypt, he made his way to the city Antino (apparently Antinoë or Antinoopolis), and thence towards the famous desert of Scete, in the Nitrian valley—then, and still, the place of many monasteries.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:138
verses.text: Here he found an unoccupied cave, in which, as a cell, he and his companion took up their abode for eight years.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:139
verses.text: His habits of life in this retreat—and (as it appears) at Edessa—were of the most austere.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:140
verses.text: His food was barley bread, varied only by parched corn, pulse, or herbs; his drink, water; his clothing, squalid rags.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:141
verses.text: His flesh was dried up like a potsherd, over his bones.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:142
verses.text: He is described as being of short stature, bald, and beardless.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:143
verses.text: He never laughed, but was of sad countenance.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:144
verses.text: Other authorities, Gregory especially, dwell much and with admiration on his profuse and perpetual weeping.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:145
verses.text: In this Egyptian retreat he is related to have proved himself a victorious adversary against the Arians.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:146
verses.text: On his arrival he had sought out and found a monk named Bishoi, to whom, because of his special sanctity, he had been divinely directed before he quitted Edessa; and with him he had sojourned for a week, communing with him by means of a miraculous gift which endowed each with the language of the other.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:147
verses.text: By this gift he was enabled to carry on controversy with Egyptian heretics, many of whom he reclaimed to orthodoxy.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:148
verses.text: Over one of these, an aged monk who had been perverted to heresy by the possession of a demon, he exercised a further miraculous power for his restoration, by casting out the evil spirit and restoring the old man at once to his right mind and to the right faith.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:149
verses.text: This gift of language, and the intercourse of Ephraim with Bishoi, are told only in the Vatican form of the History, which adds that he not only spoke Egyptian, but wrote discourses in that tongue.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:150
verses.text: The other version of it represents him as having learned to speak Egyptian in the ordinary way.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:151
verses.text: It is to be noted that the name of Bishoi (in Greek, Pasoës) is known as that of the founder (in the fourth century) of the monastery of Amba Bishoi, still occupied by a community of monks, in the Nitrian Desert; and that in those sequestered regions the tradition of Ephraim's visit to Bishoi was lingering even within the last century and probably still lingers.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:152
verses.text: To this subject we shall have occasion to recur, further on.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:154
verses.text: Visit to St.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:155
verses.text: Basil of Caesarea.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:156
verses.text: —This long sojourn ended, he resumed his purpose of visiting Basil, and left Egypt for Caesarea (which our narrator evidently supposes to be a maritime city—probably confusing it with the Caesarea which was the metropolis of Palestine).

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:157
verses.text: He was anxious that his first sight of the great Archbishop should be on the Feast of the Epiphany, and he succeeded in so timing his journey as to arrive the day before that Feast.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:158
verses.text: On enquiry, he learned that Basil would take his part in its celebration in the great church; and thither accordingly on the morrow he and his interpreter repaired.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:159
verses.text: On the same day (adds our historian) was the commemoration of St.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:160
verses.text: Mamas.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:161
verses.text: At first, when he saw the great Prelate in gorgeous vestments attended by his train of richly-robed clergy, the heart of the humble ascetic failed him: this man so surrounded with state and splendor could not be (he thought) the pillar of fire revealed to him in his vision.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:162
verses.text: But when Basil ascended the bema to preach, Ephraim, though he could understand little if anything of the orator's eloquence, was speedily brought to another mind.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:163
verses.text: As he listened he saw the Holy Ghost (in the form of a dove, says Gregory, as also the Vatican History,—or, according to another account, of a tongue of fire), speaking from his mouth, (Gregory says, hovering by his ear and inspiring his words); and he joined in the applause which each period of the oration drew from the audience,—so vehemently that while others were content to utter the cry of approval (ahâ) but once, he reiterated it (ahâ, ahâ).

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:164
verses.text: Basil noticing this sent his Archdeacon to invite the stranger into the Sanctuary; but the invitation was modestly declined.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:165
verses.text: Another version of the story places this invitation before the sermon, attributing to Basil a spiritual insight which discerned the holy man's presence and identified him.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:166
verses.text: Again the Archdeacon was sent to summon him—this time, by name: "Come, my lord Ephraim, before the bema; the Archbishop bids thee".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:167
verses.text: Amazed to find himself thus discovered, Ephraim yielded, and praised God, saying, "Great art Thou in very truth; Basil is the pillar of fire; through his mouth speaks the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:168
verses.text: He begged, however, to be excused from coming into the Archbishop's presence publicly, and asked to be allowed instead to salute him privately in the "Treasury," "after the Sacred Oblation".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:169
verses.text: Accordingly, when "the Divine Mysteries" had been completed, the Archbishop's Syncellus repeated the invitation, saying, "Draw near, Apostle of Christ, that we may enjoy thy presence".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:170
verses.text: He complied, and in his mean rags, silent, and with downcast looks, stood before the magnificent Prelate.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:171
verses.text: Basil rose from his seat, received him with the kiss of brotherhood, then bowed his head, and even prostrated himself before the humble monk, greeting him as the "Father of the Desert," the foe of unclean spirits; and asked the purpose of his journey,—"Art thou come to visit one who is a sinner? The Lord reward thy labor".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:172
verses.text: He then proceeded to give the Holy Eucharist to both the strangers.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:173
verses.text: In the interchange of speech (through the interpreter) that ensued, Basil enquired how it was that one who spoke no Greek had followed his discourse with such applause.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:174
verses.text: When he heard, in reply, of the visible manifestation of the Holy Ghost, he exclaimed, "I would I were Ephraim, to be counted worthy by the Lord of such a boon!" Ephraim then entreated of him a boon; "I know, O holy man, that whatsoever thou shalt ask of God, He will give it thee: ask Him, therefore, to enable me to speak Greek".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:175
verses.text: Basil in reply disclaimed such intercessory power, but proposed that they should join in prayer for the desired gift, reminding him of the promise, "He will fulfil the desire of them that fear Him" (Ps.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:176
verses.text: cxlv.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:178
verses.text: They prayed accordingly for a long space; and when they had ceased, Basil enquired, "Why, my Lord Ephraim, receivest thou not the Order of Priesthood, which befits thee?" "Because I am a sinner," answered Ephraim (through the interpreter).

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:179
verses.text: "I would thy sins were mine!" exclaimed Basil.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:180
verses.text: He then desired Ephraim to bow his head, laid his hand on him and recited over him the Prayer of Ordination to the Diaconate, inviting him to respond.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:181
verses.text: Forthwith, to the amazement of all, Ephraim answered in Greek, with the due form, "Save, and lift me up, O God".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:182
verses.text: And thenceforth he was able to speak Greek with ease and correctness.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:183
verses.text: He persisted, however, in declining the higher Order of the Priesthood; but his interpreter was admitted both Deacon and Priest by Basil before they departed.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:184
verses.text: Their sojourn lasted about a fortnight.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:185
verses.text: Other writers, however, call Ephraim a Priest; and there is a passage where he himself seems to speak of himself, as holding the Priesthood (koh' nîyô); but Palladius, Jerome, Sozomen, and others of the best-informed writers, confirm our History.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:186
verses.text: He is in fact frequently styled Ephraim the Deacon, as if to emphasize the fact that one so high in repute never rose above that lowly rank.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:187
verses.text: Traces of Ephraim's influence are to be found in two places of Basil's writings.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:188
verses.text: It can scarcely be doubted that he points to Ephraim when (De Spiritu Sancto, xxix.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:189
verses.text: 74), in defending the familiar formula "Glory to the Father and to the Son and to the Holy Ghost,"—and again (Homil.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:190
verses.text: in Hexaêm.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:191
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:192
verses.text: 6), in explaining the action of the Spirit on the waters (Genesis i.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:193
verses.text: 2)—he appeals to the authority of an unnamed man of great knowledge and judgment, "as closely conversant with the knowledge of all that is true, as he is far removed from worldly wisdom," a "Mesopotamian," a "Syrian".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:194
verses.text: From him he says he learned—in the former instance, that "and" was to be inserted before the name of the Holy Ghost as well as before that of the Son;—and, in the latter, that the Spirit was not to be conceived as being "carried upon" the waters (as the Septuagint represents); but (as the Peshitto more truly represents the Hebrew), as "brooding upon" them, to cherish them into life—as a bird on her nest.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:195
verses.text: The verb thus variously rendered is common to the Hebrew with the cognate Syriac; and the explanation of it given by Basil is in fact found in Ephraim's extant Commentary on the passage of Genesis: but he understands the "spirit" to be the wind—not (as Basil) the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:197
verses.text: Return to Edessa.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:198
verses.text: —Ephraim's return to Edessa was hastened by the tidings that in his absence no less than nine new heresies had appeared there.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:199
verses.text: His way thither lay through Samosata; and there he fell in with a chief man of the city, a heretic, who was passing by with a train of attendant youths.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:200
verses.text: As the holy man sat by the wayside to eat bread, these followers mocked him, and one of them wantonly smote him on the cheek.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:201
verses.text: The injury was borne in meek silence; but it was speedily avenged on the smiter, by a viper which came out from under a stone whereon he sat, and bit him so that he died on the spot.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:202
verses.text: His master and companions hastened after Ephraim, and overlook him as he was begging his food in a village beyond the city which he had just passed through.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:203
verses.text: At their entreaty he turned back with them, and by his prayers restored the dead youth to life.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:204
verses.text: The nobleman and his followers, seeing this miracle, were converted to the orthodox faith.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:206
verses.text: Controversies.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:207
verses.text: —Arrived at Edessa, he engaged at once in the conflict against the multiform heresies of the place, old and new—Manichean and Marcionite, as well as Arian.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:208
verses.text: Of all the forms of error he encountered, the one that gave him most grief and trouble was that which had been originated about the year 200 by a Syrian, Bardesan.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:209
verses.text: Of this heresiarch he writes, in one of his Nisibene Hymns (the 51st; not included in the following selection):  1.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:210
verses.text: I have chanced upon tares, my brethren,  That wear the color of wheat,  To choke the good seed;  Concerning which the husbandmen are commanded,  Take them not away nor root them out;  And though the husbandmen heeded not,  The seed waxed stronger than they,  Grew and multiplied and covered and choked them.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:212
verses.text: I have chanced upon a book of Bardaisan,  And I was troubled for an hour's space;  It tainted my pure ears,  And made them a passage  For words filled with blasphemy.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:213
verses.text: I hastened to purge them  With the goodly and pure reading  Of the Scriptures of truth.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:215
verses.text: I heard as I read them  How he blasphemes justice,  And grace her fellow-worker.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:216
verses.text: For if the body be not raised,  It were foul reproach for grace,  To have created it unto corruption;  And it were slander against justice,  To send it unto destruction.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:218
verses.text: This then that I read was grievous  For soul and for body alike;  And between these partners it casts  The severance of despair.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:219
verses.text: The body it cuts off from its resurrection,  And the soul from her comrade,  And the loss which the serpent threw on us  Bardaisan counts it for gain.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:220
verses.text: The controversy against the disciples of this man gave to the literary work of Ephraim an impulse to which his fame is largely due.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:221
verses.text: His polemic in the above instance took, as we see, the form of a hymn; and his biographer informs us that it was in this controversy he first was led to adopt hymnody as a vehicle for teaching truth and confuting error.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:222
verses.text: Of his hymns we possess some which can be confidently assigned to an earlier period—the first twenty-one of the Nisibene collection (which are the Nisibene Hymns proper), belonging to the epoch of the third siege (a.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:223
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:224
verses.text: 350); but those are songs of triumph and thanksgiving, or of personal eulogy and exhortation,—not of controversy.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:225
verses.text: The idea of the controversial use of hymnody he borrowed (we are told) from his adversaries.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:226
verses.text: It appears that Harmodius, the son of Bardesan, had popularized the false teaching of his father, as embodied in a series of a hundred and fifty hymns (in profane rivalry with the Psalms of David), by setting them to attractive tunes, which caught the ear of the multitude, and inclined them to receive his doctrines.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:227
verses.text: So Ephraim himself tells us (attributing the work, however, to Bardesan solely) in his Homily (metrical) LIII.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:228
verses.text: , "Against Heretics" (not included in our selection).

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:229
verses.text: "He fashioned hymns, and joined them with tunes; and composed psalms, and brought in moods.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:230
verses.text: By weights and measures, he portioned language.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:231
verses.text: He blended for the simple poison with sweetness.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:232
verses.text: The sick will not choose the food of wholesomeness.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:233
verses.text: He would look to David, that he might be adorned with his beauty, and commended by his likeness.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:234
verses.text: An hundred and fifty psalms, he likewise composed".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:235
verses.text: To confute the heresies thus circulated, Ephraim borrowed the tunes employed by Harmodius; and his hymns, set to these tunes, soon carried the day in favor of orthodoxy, partly by the force of their truth, partly by their superior literary power, and partly by the help of a choir formed among the nuns whom he employed to sing them, morning and evening, in the churches.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:236
verses.text: Thus the rival hymnody of heresy was superseded, and the hymns of Ephraim gained the place they have ever since held in the Church, wherever Syriac is the ecclesiastical language,—even though it is no longer the vernacular.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:237
verses.text: He celebrated this victory in the following strain of triumphant imprecation:—  "Cursed be our trust [if it be] on the Seven; the aeons which Bardaisan confesses!  Anathema [be he] who says, as he said: that from them descend the rain and the dew!  Anathema who affirms, like him: that from them are the showers and the frosts!  Cursed be he who says, as he said: that from them are the snow and the ice!  [Cursed be he who affirms, like him]: that from them are the seeds for the husbandmen!  Anathema who confesses, as he confessed: that from them are the fruits for the labourer!  Anathema who believes, like him: that from them are famine and plenty!  Anathema who confesses, as he taught: that from them are summer and winter!  Anathema be on the man: and on the woman who thus speaks!  Anathema be on the house: wherein it is thus affirmed!  Anathema his doctrine which rests: its trust on the Sevenfold!  Cursed be he who reproaches his Creator: and ascribes dominion to the Seven!  Cursed be he who reads the Scriptures: and becomes a gainsayer of the Scriptures!  Cursed be he who reads the Prophets: and breaks the words of the Prophets!  Cursed be he who reads the Apostles: and abides not by their words!"  To this is subjoined a verse, the response of Balai (Balaeus) a disciple:—  "The Lord exalt thy horn: O Church that art faithful!  For the King, and the King's son: are established in thine ark".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:238
verses.text: Another demonstration of Ephraim's zeal against heresy, which the compiler of the History judiciously omits, is (unhappily for the fame of both) attested, and with evident approval, by Gregory of Nyssa.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:239
verses.text: Apollinaris, who was his contemporary, and whose erroneous teaching he held in abhorrence, had committed his heresies to writing in two volumes which he gave into the keeping of a woman, a follower of his sect.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:240
verses.text: Ephraim approached this woman and persuaded her to lend him the books, pretending that he agreed with the doctrine of their author and desired to use them in controversy against its opponents.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:241
verses.text: At her instance he returned them in a short time; but before so doing, he treated them with fish-glue in such fashion that the leaves of each cohered into a solid mass, while to outward appearance they were unharmed.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:242
verses.text: Soon after, he challenged Apollinaris to meet him in a public disputation concerning the articles of faith which the heretic had impugned.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:243
verses.text: The latter sought to decline the controversy, pleading his old age and infirmities; but consented to it,—only on condition, however, that he should be allowed to read from these volumes the statement and defence of his tenets therein written by him.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:244
verses.text: On these terms, the disputants met.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:245
verses.text: Apollinaris was called on to maintain his thesis, and his writings were placed in his hands; but when he went to open the books, it was in vain.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:246
verses.text: No part of either volume would yield to his fingers; he was obliged to desist and to retire, baffled and ashamed; in such dismay as to bring on an illness that nearly proved fatal.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:247
verses.text: Another incident of this period, related in the History, is a miracle (a genuine one this time, if true) wrought by Ephraim on a paralytic.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:248
verses.text: Seeing him as he sat and begged at the door of a church in Edessa, the holy man asked him: "Wilt thou be made whole?" "Yea, my Lord; lay thy hand on me," was the reply.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:249
verses.text: With the words, "In the Name of Christ, arise and walk," he was cured instantly; and departed, glorifying God.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:250
verses.text: At the end of four years, messengers came to him from Basil, summoning him to come and receive consecration to the Episcopate, for some see unnamed (to which, as Sozomen relates, he had been elected;—Hist.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:251
verses.text: Eccles.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:252
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:254
verses.text: When he learned their errand, he feigned madness, going to and fro in the streets in unseemly fashion, in motley garb, eating bread as he went and letting his spittle run down.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:255
verses.text: Thus he succeeded in evading the undesired elevation: the messengers, shocked at his behaviour, returned without him, and reported that they found him a madman.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:256
verses.text: "O hidden pearl of price" (cried Basil) "whom the world knows not! Ye are the madmen, and he the sane".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:257
verses.text: The city and the Mount of Edessa suffered in these days from an invasion of the Huns, who plundered, murdered, and ravished, without mercy,—not even sparing the cells and convents.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:258
verses.text: This calamity Ephraim is said to have recorded, in writings which have not reached us.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:260
verses.text: Persecution by Valens.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:261
verses.text: —From another peril the Edessenes were saved by their faith and constancy.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:262
verses.text: In the days of their Bishop Barses (361–378), the Arian Emperor Valens (364–378), in the course of his persecution of the orthodox, approached the city and summoned the inhabitants to wait upon him in his camp and hear his pleasure there.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:263
verses.text: They disregarded the command, and gathered into the great Church of St.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:264
verses.text: Thomas, where they and their Bishop continued unceasingly in prayer.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:265
verses.text: The historian Socrates, a trustworthy and early (fifth century) authority, confirms our History here; and explains that Valens had ordered their Church to be surrendered to the Arians, and was enraged against them for resisting his decree, and against his Prefect Modestus for failing to carry it out.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:266
verses.text: Valens then, finding them contumacious, ordered one of his generals (this same Modestus, according to Sozomen, who also relates the story) to enter the city and put the people to the sword.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:267
verses.text: As Modestus, who was a humane man, sought to persuade them to yield, he met a woman leading her two sons to the Church.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:268
verses.text: He strove to stop her, warning her of the danger she incurred; but her reply was, "I hear that they who fear God are to be slain, and I am in haste to win the crown with the rest".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:269
verses.text: "But what of these boys?" he asked.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:270
verses.text: "Are they thy sons?" "They are," she answered, "and we pray, both I and they, that we may be made an oblation to the Lord".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:271
verses.text: Amazed at her resolve, he reported the matter to Valens, to convince him that the Edessenes were prepared to die rather than submit.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:272
verses.text: The Emperor was moved to relent; the people and their Bishop and priests came forth; he heard their plea, was ashamed of his cruel purpose, pardoned their disobedience, and departed.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:273
verses.text: This well-attested incident is to be assigned to 371, or to the preceding or ensuing year.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:274
verses.text: This victory of faith was celebrated by Ephraim in the following verses:—  "The doors of her homes Edessa  Left open when she went forth  With the pastor to the grave, to die,  And not depart from her faith.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:275
verses.text: Let the city and fort and building  And houses be yielded to the king;  Our goods and our gold let us leave;  So we part not from our faith!  Edessa is full of chastity,  Full of prudence and understanding.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:276
verses.text: She is clad in discernment of soul;  Faith is the girdle of her loins;  Truth her armour all-prevailing;  Love her crown, all-exalting.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:277
verses.text: Christ bless them that dwell in her,  Edessa, whose name is His glory,  And the name of her champion her beauty!  City that is lady over her fellows,  City that is the shadow  Of the Jerusalem in heaven!"  After all was thus restored to peace and orthodoxy, Ephraim withdrew to his retreat on the Mount, which he is not recorded to have again quitted, save on one occasion, to be presently related.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:279
verses.text: Penitent sent to Ephraim by Basil: Basil's Death.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:280
verses.text: —The death of Basil (at the end of 378) is said by our author to have caused great grief to Ephraim, and to have been lamented by him in hymns.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:281
verses.text: But (as will be shown below) this is hardly possible, even if the latest date for Ephraim's death be accepted.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:282
verses.text: Another miraculous incident connected with Ephraim's biography, belongs to the year of Basil's death.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:283
verses.text: A woman of high rank, but of evil life, in Caesarea, being moved to penitence, wrote on a paper a full confession of her sins, and gave it to Basil, who at her entreaty laid it with prayer before the Lord.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:284
verses.text: Her repentance and his intercession prevailed so far, that the record of all her guilt disappeared from the paper, save of one sin, more heinous than the rest.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:285
verses.text: Disappointed thus of her hope of full pardon, she had recourse again to Basil, supplicating that this sin too might be wiped out.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:286
verses.text: He encouraged her to persevere in prayer, and advised her to repair to the Mount of Edessa, to Ephraim, and through him obtain her desire.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:287
verses.text: To Ephraim accordingly she made her way, and cried to him, saying, "Have pity on me, thou holy one of God".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:288
verses.text: When he heard Basil's advice and her petition, he disavowed all such power to prevail with God as Basil had ascribed to him, and advised her rather to hasten back and obtain her Archbishop's farther intercession.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:289
verses.text: She returned accordingly to Caesarea; but, as it seemed, too late: Basil had died before her arrival, and she met his corpse as it was carried to burial.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:290
verses.text: In despair, she prostrated herself in the dust, proclaimed her story to all that stood by, and upbraided the dead saint, "Woe is me, servant of God! why didst thou send me far away that I should return too late and meet thee borne to the grave! The Lord judge betwixt me and thee, who hast sent me to another, when thyself couldst have absolved me!" One of the attendant clergy, desiring to learn what was the sin for which pardon was so hard to win, took from her the paper she held, and opening found it blank.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:291
verses.text: The last and deadliest of her list had vanished like the rest: and "thus, by the prayers of Basil and of Ephraim, and by the woman's faith and perseverance, her sins were all of them blotted out".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:292
verses.text: After this occurrence, the History places the following narrative of Ephraim's last intervention in earthly concerns.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:293
verses.text: It is related likewise by Palladius (Ephraim's younger contemporary) and by Sozomen.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:295
verses.text: Exertions in Relief of Famine.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:296
verses.text: —In a season of severe famine, he ascertained that grain was being hoarded in the stores of certain persons who gave nothing to the starving poor.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:297
verses.text: When he rebuked their inhumanity, they excused themselves on the plea that none was to be found of such probity as to guarantee fairness and honesty in the distribution of relief.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:298
verses.text: Ephraim at once offered his services, and was accepted as their agent throughout the famine season, to dispense large sums as the treasurer and steward of their bounty.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:299
verses.text: Among other things, he provided three hundred letters, partly for removing the sick to stations where they were duly tended, partly for carrying the dead for interment.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:300
verses.text: A body of helpers worked with him in administering relief, and their care extended not merely through the city, but to the country and villages adjacent.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:301
verses.text: The year of dearth ended, a year of plenty ensued; Ephraim retired to his cell,—this time to leave it no more.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:302
verses.text: He died a month after the close of the charitable labours.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:303
verses.text: Of them his biographer, following for once the better instinct which recognizes higher worth in services of love than in ascetic practices or in miraculous pretensions, writes thus:—"God gave him this occasion that therein he might win the crown in the close of his life".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:305
verses.text: His Testament.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:306
verses.text: —In his Testament, which professes to have been composed in immediate anticipation of his end, he laid on his disciples a solemn charge that his body should be buried humbly, covered with no garment save his tunic (cothênô).

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:307
verses.text: Gregory of Nyssa adds that a rich friend who, though informed of his prohibition, had provided beforehand for this purpose a costly robe, was punished by the possession of an evil spirit, which tormented him until, on his confession, the dying saint relieved him, casting out the demon by prayer and laying on of hands.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:308
verses.text: From the extant Syriac of this document (which is metrical), the following have been selected as the most striking verses:  "I Ephraim am at point to die: and I write my testament;  That I may leave for all men a memorial: of whatsoever is mine,  That though it be [but] for my words: they that know me may remember me.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:309
verses.text: Woe is me, for my times are ended: and the length of my years is fulfilled;  The spinning for me is shortened: the thread is nigh unto cutting;  The oil fails in the lamp: my days are spent, yea, mine hours;  The hireling has finished his year: and the sojourner has fulfilled his season.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:310
verses.text: Around me are the summoners: on this side and that are they that lead me away.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:311
verses.text: I cry aloud, [but] none hears me: and I complain, [but] none delivers.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:312
verses.text: "Woe to thee, Ephraim, for the judgment: when thou shalt stand before the Son's judgment-seat,  And around thee they that know thee: on the right hand and the left,  Lo! there shalt thou be confounded: woe to him who is put to shame there!  Jesu, do Thou judge Ephraim: nor give his judgment to another;  For whoso has God for his Judge: he finds mercy in judgment;  For I have heard from the wise: yea, I have heard from men of knowledge,  That whoso sees the face of the King: though he has offended, he shall not die.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:313
verses.text: "By him who came down on Mount Sinai: and by him who spake on the rock,  By that Mouth which spake the "Eli": and made the bowels of creation tremble,  By him who was sold in Judah: and by him who was scourged in Jerusalem,  By the Might which was smitten on the cheek: and by the Glory which endured spitting,  By the threefold Names of fire: and by the one Assent and will,  I have not rebelled against the Church: nor against the might of God.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:314
verses.text: If in my thought I have magnified the Father: above the Son, let Him have no mercy on me!  And if I have accounted the Holy Spirit less: than God, let mine eyes be darkened!  If as I have said, I confessed not: let me go into outer darkness!  And if I speak in hypocrisy: let me burn with the wicked in fire!       "I adjure you my disciples: with adjurations that may not be loosed,  That my words be not set aside: that ye loose not my commandments.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:315
verses.text: Whoso lays me beneath the altar: he shall not see the Altar of heaven;  For it is not meet that foul stench: should be laid in the Holy Place;  Whoso has laid me within the temple: he shall not see the temple of the Kingdom.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:316
verses.text: "Take nought from me as memorial: my beloved, my brothers, my sons,  For as much as ye have a memorial: that which ye have heard of Jesus.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:317
verses.text: For if ye take aught from Ephraim: into reproach will Ephraim come;  For He, my Lord, will say unto me: 'More than in Me they have trusted in thee,  For if they had relied on Me: they had not sought a memorial from thee.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:318
verses.text: '  "Lay me not with the martyrs: for I am a sinner and unworthy,  And because of my unworthiness I fear: to be brought beside their bones;  For if stubble comes near to fire: it will scorch it, yea, devour it.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:319
verses.text: It is not that I hate their neigbourhood: because of mine unworthiness, I fear it.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:320
verses.text: "Whoso carries me on his fingers: may his hands be leprous as Gehazi!  On your shoulders carry me: and in haste conduct me [to the grave],  And as a mean man bury me: for I have worn out my days in sadness.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:321
verses.text: Why glorify ye me, O men: who before our Lord am ashamed?  And why give ye me [the name of] 'Blessed': who am disclosed in my works?  Should one show you my transgressions: ye would all of you spit in my face.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:322
verses.text: For if the stench of the sinner: could strike one that stood by him,  Ye would all of you flee away: from the loathsome stench of Ephraim.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:323
verses.text: "Whoso lays with me a pall: may he go forth into outer darkness!  And whoso has laid with me a shroud: may he be cast into Gehenna of fire!  In my coat and cowl shall ye bury me: for ornament beseems not the hateful,  Nor does praise profit the dead: who is laid and cast into the tomb.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:324
verses.text: "Arise, my brethren of Edessa: my lords and my sons and my fathers!  Bring whatsoever ye have vowed: to lay along with your brother,  Bring and set it before me: whatsoever ye my brethren have vowed.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:325
verses.text: While I have yet a little memory: let me set on it a price;  And let there be bought pure vessels: and let there be hired workmen therewith,  And distribution be made among the poor: the needy and them that are in want.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:326
verses.text: "Blessed is the city wherein ye dwell: Edessa, mother of the wise,  Which from the living mouth of the Son: was blessed by His Disciple.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:327
verses.text: This blessing shall abide in her: until the Holy One shall be revealed.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:328
verses.text: "Whoso withholds from me aught that he has vowed: shall die the death of Ananias,  Who sought to deceive the Apostles: and was stretched [dead] before their feet.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:329
verses.text: "Whoso carries before me a taper: may his fire be kindled beside him!  For to what end avails fire: for him whose fire is from himself?  For when the visible fire is kindled: in it is consumed the secret fire.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:330
verses.text: Sufficient for me is the pain without: add ye not to me that which is within.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:331
verses.text: "Lay me not with sweet spices: for this honour avails me not;  Nor yet incense and perfumes: for the honour benefits me not.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:332
verses.text: Burn sweet spices in the Holy Place: and me, even me, conduct to the grave with prayer.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:333
verses.text: Give ye incense to God: and over me send up hymns.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:334
verses.text: Instead of perfumes of spices: in prayer make remembrance of me.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:335
verses.text: What can goodly odour profit: to the dead who cannot perceive it?  Bring them in and burn them in the Holy Place: that they which enter in may smell the savour.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:336
verses.text: Wrap thou not the fetid dung: in silk that profits it not.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:337
verses.text: Cast it down upon the dunghill: for it cannot perceive honour [done to it].

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:338
verses.text: "Lay me not in your sepulchres: for your magnificence profits me not;  For I have a covenant with God: that I shall be buried with strangers.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:339
verses.text: I am a stranger, as they were: with them, O my brethren, lay me!  For every bird loves its kind: and man loves him that is like himself.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:340
verses.text: In the cemetery lay me: where are the broken of heart,  That when the Son of God comes: He may embrace me and raise me among them".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:341
verses.text: [After blessing by name the five faithful disciples above mentioned (page 126), he leaves an anathema on the two, Paulinus and Urit, who had erred from the faith; and against]  "Arians and Anomoeans: Cathari and those of the Serpent,  Marcionites and Manichoeans: Bardesanites and Kukites,  Paulites and Vitalianites: Sabbatarians and Borborites,  With all the other doctrines: of superstitious that are unseemly".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:342
verses.text: [The dying Saint recalls in the following lines the vision of his childhood, and praises God for its fulfilment.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:343
verses.text: ]  "I swear by your lives I lie not: in this thing that I tell.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:344
verses.text: For when I was a little child: and lay in my mother's bosom,  I saw (I was as in a dream): a thing which has come to pass in truth.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:345
verses.text: There grew a vine-shoot on my tongue: and increased and reached unto heaven,  And it yielded fruit without measure: leaves likewise without number.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:346
verses.text: It spread, it stretched wide, it bore fruit: all creation drew near,  And the more they were that gathered: the more its clusters abounded.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:347
verses.text: These clusters were the Homilies; and these leaves the Hymns.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:348
verses.text: God was the giver of them: glory to Him for His grace!  For He gave to me of His good pleasure: from the storehouse of His treasures".

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:349
verses.text: This farewell strain has no doubt suffered interpolation, but the main part of what is above translated is confirmed as genuine by the references to it of Gregory, who had undoubtedly read it in a Greek version.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:350
verses.text: As it has reached us, it ends with a narrative, which at most can only claim to be an appendix added by a disciple, of the lamentations uttered at his deathbed by a maiden named Lamprotate, daughter of a man of rank in Edessa, who entreated permission to make a tomb for him and another at his feet for herself.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:351
verses.text: The narrative concludes with his consent to this petition, his parting commands to her, and her promise of obedience.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:352
verses.text: His body was followed to the grave by all the people of the city and neighborhood, and by the Bishops, priests, and deacons of the province, with the monks, whether "anchorites, stylites, or coenobites"—solitary, or living in communities.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:353
verses.text: It was laid (as he had desired) in the strangers' burial-ground; but not long after, the citizens removed it thence, and made a grave for him, deacon as he was, among those of their Bishops,—probably in the monastery (now belonging to the Armenians) of St.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:354
verses.text: Sergius on the Mount of Edessa, where his tomb is shown to this day, as we learn from the Reise in Syr.

verses.text: —His death occurred in Haziran (June), on the 15th according to our History (Vat.

verses.text: The shorter Syriac Life gives the year as 372,—thus contradicting the History which represents him as living in the year of Basil's death (378).

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:364
verses.text: Even in the time of Gregory of Nyssa, an annual commemoration of Ephraim had become customary in the Church, which gave occasion for the Encomium above referred to.

verses.name: Ephraim the Syrian 3:365
